section.title: Installation of &carrot;
section.para: &carrot;'s modular architecture is very flexible, but also brings several difficult issues concerning its installation. Every component can be installed in a different web context, some of them even on physically different machines. Components must be configured and processes of using those components defined. While most of these tasks are trivial, they still require certain amount of work.

section.title: Installation requirements
section.para: The components contained in the binary distribution are written in Java and packaged as Web Application Archives (WAR files). A web server capable of deploying WAR archives is therefore required. &tomcat; is the recommended web server, although other possibilities exist like &jboss; or &resin;. This manual details the configuration of &tomcat; web server for use with &carrot;. Installation on other containers should be similar.

&java; virtual machine in at least version 1.3 is required, although version 1.4+ is recommended. The application should work on all vendors' JVMs, although problems have been reported in installation on IBM's JDK.
For building the system from source code, a Java compiler (JDK) and &ant; build tool are also required.

section.title: Choosing components
section.para: The first step is to choose components, which your &carrot; installation will use. Several components are already provided in the base &carrot; &cvs;, other may be available from independent vendors (we hope ;). More information about the available components and their locations can be found at the official project website: &carrot-web;.

It is important to think of the required components in terms of processes in which they will be linked. For example, in order to build an intranet search engine one should install some input component (some wrappers for existing search engines are provided in the distribution), a stemming filter improving the quality of clustering interface, LSI clustering filter for organizing search results into groups and an output component for rendering the result, such as xslt-renderer with an appropriate stylesheet. The result can be seen in .

section.para: A good help in creating custom processes is taking a look at the templates saved directly from the &carrot; &cvs;. descriptors-templates folder in the distribution provides several processes which can serve as a basis for customization (please refer to for more information about descriptor files).

section.title: Building components from sources
section.para: In order to build Carrot2's components, you must have ANT in your path. We use ANT 1.6, lower versions are not supported but may work.

This command should build all the components for you and place them in tmp/dist.
ant build

Note that the Web controller component is built with a set of component descriptors for which service &url;s are hardcoded inside the descriptor files. To change the defaults, use the following &ant; command:
Adjust the parameters to match your deployment configuration.

section.title: Downloading pre-built components
section.para: The nightly build process produces a set of WAR files which can be used to install &carrot; without a need to compile the system from source files. Please note that the controller component will require some manual adjustments in &url;s hardcoded in components descriptors.
Nightly binaries are available at: .

section.title: Web controller component configuration
section.para: The Web controller component is the glue combining other &carrot; components. The current controller component is a web application that mimics a search engine (although other controllers may not look like that at all :).
The configuration files for the controller component can be found in controller/WEB-INF/ folder of the distribution.

section.title: Query response caches and their configuration
section.para: cache-config.xml is a configuration file for the internal cache of the controller component. Caching makes sense if input components are either slow in responding to queries, or there are restrictions put on their use (the case with most search engines on the Web). Input component's response is cached for each unique combination of a query, requested number of results and optional parameters passed to the input component by the controller (or the process script). When such unique combination of attributes is requested again, the input component's response is simulated by the stream taken from the cache.

The cache subsystem is implemented as a cascade of containers. The top-level caches should have a fast access (like memory-based caches), caches down the cascading chain can be slower (disk access or database storage). When a query is first added to cache, it is added to the top-container and descends down the chain if it is not reused, finally it is removed from the cache if the maximum capacity of the last container has been reached.

section.title: Main configuration file
section.para: carrot-config.xml is the main configuration file of the controller. It contains references to folders where component and process descriptors are located, name of the cache configuration file and other information. This section goes through the elements of the configuration file and describes their meaning.

callout.para: reloadable attribute allows the controller component to dynamically reload while it is active and when the configuration file changes. This attribute should be set to true only during debugging or initial deployment, when component processes are often changed.
components defines a web application context-relative directory where component descriptors can be found. Refer to section for more information about component descriptors.
processes defines a web application context-relative directory where process definitions can be found. Refer to section for more information about process descriptors.
cache specifies a web application context-relative path where cache configuration file can be found. This file is described in .
guards specifies a web application context-relative directory where query guards definition can be found. The guards specification is defined in .

section.title: Modifying component and process descriptors
section.para: A component descriptor is an &xml; file that provides the required information about the type and services provided by a component. The structure of a component descriptor file is defined in an &xmlschema;, which can be found in schema/component-descriptor.xsd file in the distribution.

A detailed definition of a descriptor file can be found on the Internet at &carrot-web;, more specifically in chapter Component descriptors in the &devmanual;. The most important properties of a component are highligted below.

callout.para: This is the identification string assigned to the component. It is usually assigned by &carrot; project maintainers and should not be changed individually as it may name clash with other components. The id of a component is used in process definitions and is very important.
The type of the component. input, output or filter values are possible.

The &url; at which component's services are available to the controller. The data exchange formats and specification is described in detail in the &devmanual;, and they should normally be part of specification of any component. The example component descriptors in descriptor-templates cover the data formats accepted by the components released in the distribution.

tip.para: The &url; of a component must be available to the controller, but not necessarily to the "outside world". Web application container (such as Tomcat) can be configured in such a way to allow local connections (from the controller), but refuse any attempts to connect to components directly.

callout.para: When deploying your &carrot; installation, modify &url; of the components replacing host and port according to your individual environment.
The information and configuration page of the component. These can (and should) be removed from component descriptor in the final deployment.

section.para: Processes define the way data is transformed by separate components yielding the final result. Process descriptor files thus specify a chain of components from the input through filters, to the output component. The result returned from the output component is then shown on user's browser (or any other devide the controller component might support).

callout.para: The identification string of a process. This string can be assigned according to one's imagination, although it must be unique within the set of processed defined for one controller. Also, the id of a process is used to find its localized name in the application resources (i18n.xml file in the controller distribution).
The default name of a process if its localized name cannot be found in application's resources.
If set to true, the controller will attempt to use cached input prior to sending requests to the input component specified later on.
If set to true, the controller component will cache the data received from this process's input component.
This method invokes the input component for the given query and retrieves an InputStream with the results. Replace the component id to that your input component here.

This method invokes the filter component on the data stream. Here, LSI clustering component is invoked with some custom parameters specified above the invocation line. Replace the component id to that your filter component here (refer to examples in the distribution).
More than one filter can be applied to the data stream. Just apply whatever filters sequentially to the InputStream object instance.

Invokes the output component for the current data stream. Here, dynamic tree component is invoked with certain customized parameters. Replace the component id to that your output component here (refer to examples in the distribution).
Sends the reponse back to the client. This method must be called at the end of the process script.

section.para: The details of process programming are beyond the limits of this guide (most often the only required change will be adjusting the &url;s to components in ). The best way to start is by taking a look at examples in the distribution.

section.title: Query/ component guards
section.para: There exist situations in which queries to a component should be limited. For example, some components may not be available at certain time frames, some may restrict the number of queries to certain limits etc. The guards describe such constraints – they are executed before any component is invoked by the controller. If any guard vetoes the access to a given component, execution of a query is stopped and the information is displayed to the user.
Guards specification is not yet released to the public.

important.para: If any guard files are present in the official distribution of &carrot;, you must not remove them, disable them, or change them in any way.

section.title: Deploying &carrot; on &tomcat;
section.para: This section provides essential steps leading to installing &carrot; on &tomcat; web server. It is assumed here that &java; (JDK) is already installed.

listitem.para: Download and unpack &tomcat; web server from . At the moment of writing, we suggest stable release 4.1.24.

Copy shared libraries from lib folder of the &cvs; distribution to shared/lib of your tomcat installation. Alternatively, you can download a ZIPped pack of shared libraries from the nightly binaries dropoff zone ().
Build the controller component specifying the deployment host and port so that component descriptors point at valid &url;s. Copy the controller component to webapps folder of &tomcat;.
Copy all *.war files (components) to webapps folder of your &tomcat;. The components will be automatically deployed when &tomcat; is started next time.
You may also want to configure &log4j; so that messages from &carrot; components are properly saved somewhere. Create and edit conf/log4j.properties in your &tomcat; installation. Type the following:

informalexample.programlisting:
# Default logging sink. log4j.rootLogger=DEBUG,global.file
# global.file appender (/logs/carrot2.log)
log4j.appender.global.file=org.apache.log4j.FileAppender log4j.appender.global.file.File=TRANSLATE_CONTEXT::/logs/carrot2.log log4j.appender.global.file.Append=true log4j.appender.global.file.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout log4j.appender.global.file.layout.ConversionPattern=%d %-5p [%t] %c{2} -- %m%n

listitem.para: Make sure your port number 8080 is not already taken by some other application. Then start &tomcat; using the startup script appropriate for your platform (either bin/startup.bat or bin/startup.sh. Wait until message INFO: Starting Coyote HTTP/1.1 on port 8080 shows up on the console. This may take even a couple of minutes because WAR applications must be deployed and JSP files compiled.
Open a web browser (&javascript; must be enabled, Internet Explorer or Mozilla is recommended) and point it to , you should see &carrot;'s query page like below.

Now follow Demo link on the top of the query page and select any of the cached preconfigured queries. A clustered result should be available within seconds (please allow for the components to initialize if queried for the first time).
